Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: The child is caught stealing snacks at a store, and the parent needs to handle the situation
Expectation2: Communicate clearly and empathetically with patients and their families
Situation2: A patient is at a routine check-up and has general questions about their health.
Story: I was standing in the grocery store, my white coat still on from a long shift, when I saw my son slip a candy bar into his pocket. My heart sank. As a parent, I knew I had to teach him right from wrong, to guide him with patience and discipline. But just as I was about to address him, my phone buzzed. It was the clinic—Mrs. Patel, my patient, was waiting for her check-up and had questions about her health. She was anxious, and I knew she needed my full attention and empathy. I felt torn, the weight of both roles pressing down on me. My son’s wide, guilty eyes pleaded for understanding, while my professional duty called for calm, clear communication with a worried patient. I could feel the expectations pulling me in opposite directions, my mind racing as I tried to figure out how to be the parent my son needed and the doctor my patient deserved, all at the same time.
